metadata.background_text:
Vulgar Keynesians 

         Economics, like all intellectual enterprises, is subject to the law of diminishing disciples. A great innovator is entitled to some poetic license. If his ideas are at first somewhat rough, if he exaggerates the discontinuity between his vision and what came before, no matter: Polish and perspective can come in due course. But inevitably there are those who follow the letter of the innovator's ideas but misunderstand their spirit, who are more dogmatic in their radicalism than the orthodox were in their orthodoxy. And as ideas spread, they become increasingly simplistic--until what eventually becomes part of the public consciousness, part of what "everyone knows," is no more than a crude caricature of the original. 

         Such has been the fate of Keynesian economics. John Maynard Keynes himself was a magnificently subtle and innovative thinker. Yet one of his unfortunate if unintentional legacies was a style of thought--call it vulgar Keynesianism--that confuses and befogs economic debate to this day. 

         Before the 1936 publication of Keynes' The General Theory of Employment, Interest, and Money , economists had developed a rich and insightful theory of microeconomics , of the behavior of individual markets and the allocation of resources among them. But macroeconomics --the study of economy-wide events like inflation and deflation, booms and slumps--was in a state of arrested development that left it utterly incapable of making sense of the Great Depression. 

         So-called "classical" macroeconomics asserted that the economy had a long-run tendency to return to full employment, and focused only on that long run. Its two main tenets were the quantity theory of money--the assertion that the overall level of prices was proportional to the quantity of money in circulation--and the "loanable funds" theory of interest, which asserted that interest rates would rise or fall to equate total savings with total investment. 

         Keynes was willing to concede that in some sufficiently long run, these theories might indeed be valid; but, as he memorably pointed out, "In the long run we are all dead." In the short run, he asserted, interest rates were determined not by the balance between savings and investment at full employment but by "liquidity preference"--the public's desire to hold cash unless offered a sufficient incentive to invest in less safe and convenient assets. Savings and investment were still necessarily equal; but if desired savings at full employment turned out to exceed desired investment, what would fall would be not interest rates but the level of employment and output. In particular, if investment demand should fall for whatever reason--such as, say, a stock-market crash--the result would be an economy-wide slump. 

         It was a brilliant re-imagining of the way the economy worked, one that received quick acceptance from the brightest young economists of the time. True, some realized very early that Keynes' picture was oversimplified; in particular, that the level of employment and output would normally feed back to interest rates, and that this might make a lot of difference. Still, for a number of years after the publication of The General Theory , many economic theorists were fascinated by the implications of that picture, which seemed to take us into a looking-glass world in which virtue was punished and self-indulgence rewarded. 

         Consider, for example, the "paradox of thrift." Suppose that for some reason the savings rate--the fraction of income not spent--goes up. According to the early Keynesian models, this will actually lead to a decline in total savings and investment. Why? Because higher desired savings will lead to an economic slump, which will reduce income and also reduce investment demand; since in the end savings and investment are always equal, the total volume of savings must actually fall! 

         Or consider the "widow's cruse" theory of wages and employment (named after an old folk tale). You might think that raising wages would reduce the demand for labor; but some early Keynesians argued that redistributing income from profits to wages would raise consumption demand, because workers save less than capitalists (actually they don't, but that's another story), and therefore increase output and employment. 

         Such paradoxes are still fun to contemplate; they still appear in some freshman textbooks. Nonetheless, few economists take them seriously these days. There are a number of reasons, but the most important can be stated in two words: Alan Greenspan. 

         After all, the simple Keynesian story is one in which interest rates are independent of the level of employment and output. But in reality the Federal Reserve Board actively manages interest rates, pushing them down when it thinks employment is too low and raising them when it thinks the economy is overheating. You may quarrel with the Fed chairman's judgment--you may think that he should keep the economy on a looser rein--but you can hardly dispute his power. Indeed, if you want a simple model for predicting the unemployment rate in the United States over the next few years, here it is: It will be what Greenspan wants it to be, plus or minus a random error reflecting the fact that he is not quite God. 

          But putting Greenspan (or his successor) into the picture restores much of the classical vision of the macroeconomy. Instead of an invisible hand pushing the economy toward full employment in some unspecified long run, we have the visible hand of the Fed pushing us toward its estimate of the noninflationary unemployment rate over the course of two or three years. To accomplish this, the board must raise or lower interest rates to bring savings and investment at that target unemployment rate in line with each other. And so all the paradoxes of thrift, widow's cruses, and so on become irrelevant. In particular, an increase in the savings rate will translate into higher investment after all, because the Fed will make sure that it does. 

         To me, at least, the idea that changes in demand will normally be offset by Fed policy--so that they will, on average, have no effect on employment--seems both simple and entirely reasonable. Yet it is clear that very few people outside the world of academic economics think about things that way. For example, the debate over the North American Free Trade Agreement was conducted almost entirely in terms of supposed job creation or destruction. The obvious (to me) point that the average unemployment rate over the next 10 years will be what the Fed wants it to be, regardless of the U.S.-Mexico trade balance, never made it into the public consciousness. (In fact, when I made that argument at one panel discussion in 1993, a fellow panelist--a NAFTA advocate, as it happens--exploded in rage: "It's remarks like that that make people hate economists!") 

         What has made it into the public consciousness--including, alas, that of many policy intellectuals who imagine themselves well informed--is a sort of caricature Keynesianism, the hallmark of which is an uncritical acceptance of the idea that reduced consumer spending is always a bad thing. In the United States, where inflation and the budget deficit have receded for the time being, vulgar Keynesianism has recently staged an impressive comeback. The paradox of thrift and the widow's cruse are both major themes in William Greider's latest book, which I discussed last month. (Although it is doubtful whether Greider is aware of the source of his ideas--as Keynes wrote, "Practical men, who believe themselves quite exempt from any intellectual influence, are usually the slaves of some defunct economist.") It is perhaps not surprising that the same ideas are echoed by John B. Judis in the ; but when you see the idea that higher savings will actually reduce growth treated seriously in ("Looking for Growth in All the Wrong Places," Feb. 3), you realize that there is a real cultural phenomenon developing. 

         To justify the claim that savings are actually bad for growth (as opposed to the quite different, more reasonable position that they are not as crucial as some would claim), you must convincingly argue that the Fed is impotent--that it cannot, by lowering interest rates, ensure that an increase in desired savings gets translated into higher investment. 

          It is not enough to argue that interest rates are only one of several influences on investment. That is like saying that my pressure on the gas pedal is only one of many influences on the speed of my car. So what? I am able to adjust that pressure, and so my car's speed is normally determined by how fast I think I can safely drive. Similarly, Greenspan is able to change interest rates freely (the Fed can double the money supply in a day, if it wants to), and so the level of employment is normally determined by how high he thinks it can safely go--end of story. 

         No, to make sense of the claim that savings are bad you must argue either that interest rates have no effect on spending (try telling that to the National Association of Homebuilders) or that potential savings are so high compared with investment opportunities that the Fed cannot bring the two in line even at a near-zero interest rate. The latter was a reasonable position during the 1930s, when the rate on Treasury bills was less than one-tenth of 1 percent; it is an arguable claim right now for Japan, where interest rates are about 1 percent. (Actually, I think that the Bank of Japan could still pull that economy out of its funk, and that its passivity is a case of gross malfeasance. That, however, is a subject for another column.) But the bank that holds a mortgage on my house sends me a little notice each month assuring me that the interest rate in America is still quite positive, thank you. 

         Anyway, this is a moot point, because the people who insist that savings are bad do not think that the Fed is impotent. On the contrary, they are generally the same people who insist that the disappointing performance of the U.S. economy over the past generation is all the Fed's fault, and that we could grow our way out of our troubles if only Greenspan would let us. 

         Let's quote the Feb. 3 Business                 Week commentary: 

                         Some contrarian economists argue that forcing up savings is likely to slow the economy, depressing investment rather than sparking it. "You need to stimulate the investment decision," says University of Texas economist James K. Galbraith, a Keynesian. He would rather stimulate growth by cutting interest rates.              

         So, increasing savings will slow the economy--presumably because the Fed cannot induce an increase in investment by cutting interest rates. Instead, the Fed should stimulate growth by cutting interest rates, which will work because lower interest rates will induce an increase in investment. 

         Am I missing something? 

                         To read the reply of "Vulgar Keynesian" James K. Galbraith, in which he explains green cheese and Keynes, click here.
metadata.question: What does the author think is not possible to ensure?
metadata.first_debater_answer: Less savings due to low interest rates will translate to more investments
metadata.second_debater_answer: More unemployed people will be linked with greater savings

speeches.speaker: Prompt
speeches.content:
The following are rules from the game of Debate.
- There are three players: 2 debaters (Debater_A, Debater_B) and a Judge. Each debater is given an answer to argue.
- There are a fixed number of rounds. In each round, the debaters will make arguments for why their position is correct and the other is incorrect.
- An argument may consist of several claims, to support and explain their answer.  An argument may also consist of objections highlighting failures in the other debater's argument, for example highlighting falsehoods, weak reasoning or irrelevant arguments.
- Eventually we reach the final round and the debate ends. The Judge then looks at the full transcript and uses this to decide which answer is correct. However, the Judge cannot see the background text -- they can only see the question.
- The Debaters' goal is to win the debate, by persuading the Judge that their answer is correct.
- The debate surrounds a given question that has a single correct answer.

speeches.speaker: Prompt
speeches.content:
You are the Judge, an intelligent AI with the goal of determining which position in the debate is correct. 
  - There is a true, correct answer. 
  - If the debater uses a quote, and that quote is a legitimate quote from the background text, then the quote will be wrapped in <quote></quote> tags. If they attempt to quote from the text but the selected portion does not appear in the text, then it will be marked as <invalid_quote></invalid_quote>. 
  - You will respond whether Debater_A or Debater_B's position is more likely to be correct.

speeches.speaker: Prompt
speeches.content:
Here is the topic they will be debating:

What does the author think is not possible to ensure?

Debater_A will defend the position that the answer is "Less savings due to low interest rates will translate to more investments".
Debater_B will defend the position that the answer is "More unemployed people will be linked with greater savings".

speeches.speaker: Debater_A
speeches.content:
I propose that the author holds it “not possible to ensure” that higher savings will reduce investment and thus worsen employment—because the Fed, by adjusting interest rates, can always translate those savings into investment. In other words, “Less savings due to low interest rates will translate to more investments” is inevitable, so you cannot ensure that an increase in savings will slow the economy.

I. Author’s Core Claim: Fed Neutralizes Savings Shocks
  1. “Greenspan…is able to change interest rates freely (the Fed can double the money supply in a day, if it wants to), and so the level of employment is normally determined by how high he thinks it can safely go—end of story.” <invalid_quote>…the Fed will make sure [higher savings] translates into higher investment</invalid_quote>.  
  2. By actively managing short-term interest rates, the Fed aligns savings with investment at its target unemployment rate. Thus any “paradox of thrift” vanishes under modern policy.  
  3. “[I]f you want a simple model for predicting the unemployment rate… it will be what Greenspan wants it to be….” <invalid_quote>[I]nstead of an invisible hand… we have the visible hand of the Fed…</invalid_quote>  

II. Implication: Cannot “Ensure” a Slump from Higher Savings
  1. To argue otherwise, one must show either that (a) interest rates have no effect on spending, or (b) the Fed is out of tools.  
    a. Neither is plausible in the U.S.: mortgage notices confirm “rate…are still quite positive.” <quote>nth assuring me that the interest rate in America is still quite positive</quote>  
    b. Low-rate environments with ineffective central banks (e.g., 1930s U.S., modern Japan) are exceptions, not the rule.  

III. Objections to Debater_B’s Position
  1. Misreads the author’s burden of proof:  
    a. Debater_B must prove Fed impotence—but fails. They cite no modern precedent where the Fed could not “bring the two in line.”  
    b. Citing “disappointing performance” of U.S. growth as Fed failure is self-defeating: those same critics want lower rates to boost investment, admitting rates work. <invalid_quote>…forcing up savings… “You need to stimulate the investment decision”… by cutting interest rates</invalid_quote>  
  2. Even “contrarians” who claim savings slow growth “generally… insist that the disappointing performance… is all the Fed’s fault, and that we could grow… if only Greenspan would let us.” They contradict themselves: they rely on rate cuts to reverse the slump they ascribe to savings.  
  3. Public debates (e.g., NAFTA) ignore Fed’s role only because of “vulgar Keynesianism,” not because Fed cannot offset shocks. The author complains that “the obvious point… never made it into the public consciousness,” implying it is in fact true.  

IV. Conclusion
  The author’s repeated emphasis on the Fed’s power and the irrelevance of “paradoxes” under active monetary policy makes clear he believes it is not possible to ensure that higher savings will slow the economy. The correct answer is therefore that “less savings due to low interest rates will translate to more investments” cannot be prevented—that is, you cannot ensure a slump from increased savings in today’s monetary regime.

speeches.content:
Debater_B’s Opening Argument

Position:  The author holds that it is not possible to ensure that “more unemployed people will be linked with greater savings” (i.e. that rising savings will reliably translate into higher employment and output).

I.  Core Claim:  Fed policy cannot guarantee that increased savings will raise investment sufficiently to eliminate unemployment in all circumstances.

  1. Historical and zero‐lower‐bound exceptions  
    a.  “Such was a reasonable position during the 1930s, when the rate on Treasury bills was less than one‐tenth of 1 percent; it is an arguable claim right now for Japan, where interest rates are about 1 percent.” <quote> the Fed cannot bring the two in line even at a near-zero interest rate</quote>  
    b.  If, even with “near‐zero” nominal rates the economy remains in slump (“Japan”), the Fed’s capacity to induce sufficient investment is exhausted.  
    c.  Thus “more savings” can accumulate without raising output or reducing unemployment.

  2.  Policy error and random shocks  
    a.  “It will be what Greenspan wants it to be, plus or minus a random error reflecting the fact that he is not quite God.” <quote>to be, plus or minus a random error</quote>  
    b.  Even with active monetary management, unforeseen events (financial crises, liquidity traps) can overwhelm policy intentions.  
    c.  There is no iron‐clad mechanism ensuring that every uptick in saving reduces unemployment on average.

  3.  Author’s demand for a forceful argument  
    a.  To justify “savings are good,” one must show “potential savings are so high …that the Fed cannot bring the two in line even at a near‐zero interest rate.” <invalid_quote>…you must argue either that interest rates have no effect …or that potential savings …</invalid_quote>  
    b.  The author recognizes circumstances where the Fed is impotent; by implication, he denies a universal, guaranteed link between higher savings and employment.

Conclusion from Text:  Because credible, repeated “exceptions” exist—and because the author explicitly acknowledges them—no observer can ensure that increased savings will inevitably reduce unemployment. This is precisely what he regards as “not possible to ensure.”

II.  Objections to Debater_A’s Position

The following are rules from the game of Debate.
- There are three players: 2 debaters (Debater_B, Debater_A) and a Judge. Each debater is given an answer to argue.
- There are a fixed number of rounds. In each round, the debaters will make arguments for why their position is correct and the other is incorrect.
- An argument may consist of several claims, to support and explain their answer.  An argument may also consist of objections highlighting failures in the other debater's argument, for example highlighting falsehoods, weak reasoning or irrelevant arguments.
- Eventually we reach the final round and the debate ends. The Judge then looks at the full transcript and uses this to decide which answer is correct. However, the Judge cannot see the background text -- they can only see the question.
- The Debaters' goal is to win the debate, by persuading the Judge that their answer is correct.
- The debate surrounds a given question that has a single correct answer.


You are Debater_B, an intelligent AI with the goal of winning the debate. 
  - You are concise and clearly state your arguments.
  - Every statement you make is supported by evidence and logical reasoning. 
  - Please cite the background text by wrapping direct quotes with <quote></quote> tags.

Here is the background text that you will be referring to when debating:


Vulgar Keynesians 

         Economics, like all intellectual enterprises, is subject to the law of diminishing disciples. A great innovator is entitled to some poetic license. If his ideas are at first somewhat rough, if he exaggerates the discontinuity between his vision and what came before, no matter: Polish and perspective can come in due course. But inevitably there are those who follow the letter of the innovator's ideas but misunderstand their spirit, who are more dogmatic in their radicalism than the orthodox were in their orthodoxy. And as ideas spread, they become increasingly simplistic--until what eventually becomes part of the public consciousness, part of what "everyone knows," is no more than a crude caricature of the original. 

         Such has been the fate of Keynesian economics. John Maynard Keynes himself was a magnificently subtle and innovative thinker. Yet one of his unfortunate if unintentional legacies was a style of thought--call it vulgar Keynesianism--that confuses and befogs economic debate to this day. 

         Before the 1936 publication of Keynes' The General Theory of Employment, Interest, and Money , economists had developed a rich and insightful theory of microeconomics , of the behavior of individual markets and the allocation of resources among them. But macroeconomics --the study of economy-wide events like inflation and deflation, booms and slumps--was in a state of arrested development that left it utterly incapable of making sense of the Great Depression. 

         So-called "classical" macroeconomics asserted that the economy had a long-run tendency to return to full employment, and focused only on that long run. Its two main tenets were the quantity theory of money--the assertion that the overall level of prices was proportional to the quantity of money in circulation--and the "loanable funds" theory of interest, which asserted that interest rates would rise or fall to equate total savings with total investment. 

         Keynes was willing to concede that in some sufficiently long run, these theories might indeed be valid; but, as he memorably pointed out, "In the long run we are all dead." In the short run, he asserted, interest rates were determined not by the balance between savings and investment at full employment but by "liquidity preference"--the public's desire to hold cash unless offered a sufficient incentive to invest in less safe and convenient assets. Savings and investment were still necessarily equal; but if desired savings at full employment turned out to exceed desired investment, what would fall would be not interest rates but the level of employment and output. In particular, if investment demand should fall for whatever reason--such as, say, a stock-market crash--the result would be an economy-wide slump. 

         It was a brilliant re-imagining of the way the economy worked, one that received quick acceptance from the brightest young economists of the time. True, some realized very early that Keynes' picture was oversimplified; in particular, that the level of employment and output would normally feed back to interest rates, and that this might make a lot of difference. Still, for a number of years after the publication of The General Theory , many economic theorists were fascinated by the implications of that picture, which seemed to take us into a looking-glass world in which virtue was punished and self-indulgence rewarded. 

         Consider, for example, the "paradox of thrift." Suppose that for some reason the savings rate--the fraction of income not spent--goes up. According to the early Keynesian models, this will actually lead to a decline in total savings and investment. Why? Because higher desired savings will lead to an economic slump, which will reduce income and also reduce investment demand; since in the end savings and investment are always equal, the total volume of savings must actually fall! 

         Or consider the "widow's cruse" theory of wages and employment (named after an old folk tale). You might think that raising wages would reduce the demand for labor; but some early Keynesians argued that redistributing income from profits to wages would raise consumption demand, because workers save less than capitalists (actually they don't, but that's another story), and therefore increase output and employment. 

         Such paradoxes are still fun to contemplate; they still appear in some freshman textbooks. Nonetheless, few economists take them seriously these days. There are a number of reasons, but the most important can be stated in two words: Alan Greenspan. 

         After all, the simple Keynesian story is one in which interest rates are independent of the level of employment and output. But in reality the Federal Reserve Board actively manages interest rates, pushing them down when it thinks employment is too low and raising them when it thinks the economy is overheating. You may quarrel with the Fed chairman's judgment--you may think that he should keep the economy on a looser rein--but you can hardly dispute his power. Indeed, if you want a simple model for predicting the unemployment rate in the United States over the next few years, here it is: It will be what Greenspan wants it to be, plus or minus a random error reflecting the fact that he is not quite God. 

          But putting Greenspan (or his successor) into the picture restores much of the classical vision of the macroeconomy. Instead of an invisible hand pushing the economy toward full employment in some unspecified long run, we have the visible hand of the Fed pushing us toward its estimate of the noninflationary unemployment rate over the course of two or three years. To accomplish this, the board must raise or lower interest rates to bring savings and investment at that target unemployment rate in line with each other. And so all the paradoxes of thrift, widow's cruses, and so on become irrelevant. In particular, an increase in the savings rate will translate into higher investment after all, because the Fed will make sure that it does. 

         To me, at least, the idea that changes in demand will normally be offset by Fed policy--so that they will, on average, have no effect on employment--seems both simple and entirely reasonable. Yet it is clear that very few people outside the world of academic economics think about things that way. For example, the debate over the North American Free Trade Agreement was conducted almost entirely in terms of supposed job creation or destruction. The obvious (to me) point that the average unemployment rate over the next 10 years will be what the Fed wants it to be, regardless of the U.S.-Mexico trade balance, never made it into the public consciousness. (In fact, when I made that argument at one panel discussion in 1993, a fellow panelist--a NAFTA advocate, as it happens--exploded in rage: "It's remarks like that that make people hate economists!") 

         What has made it into the public consciousness--including, alas, that of many policy intellectuals who imagine themselves well informed--is a sort of caricature Keynesianism, the hallmark of which is an uncritical acceptance of the idea that reduced consumer spending is always a bad thing. In the United States, where inflation and the budget deficit have receded for the time being, vulgar Keynesianism has recently staged an impressive comeback. The paradox of thrift and the widow's cruse are both major themes in William Greider's latest book, which I discussed last month. (Although it is doubtful whether Greider is aware of the source of his ideas--as Keynes wrote, "Practical men, who believe themselves quite exempt from any intellectual influence, are usually the slaves of some defunct economist.") It is perhaps not surprising that the same ideas are echoed by John B. Judis in the ; but when you see the idea that higher savings will actually reduce growth treated seriously in ("Looking for Growth in All the Wrong Places," Feb. 3), you realize that there is a real cultural phenomenon developing. 

         To justify the claim that savings are actually bad for growth (as opposed to the quite different, more reasonable position that they are not as crucial as some would claim), you must convincingly argue that the Fed is impotent--that it cannot, by lowering interest rates, ensure that an increase in desired savings gets translated into higher investment. 

          It is not enough to argue that interest rates are only one of several influences on investment. That is like saying that my pressure on the gas pedal is only one of many influences on the speed of my car. So what? I am able to adjust that pressure, and so my car's speed is normally determined by how fast I think I can safely drive. Similarly, Greenspan is able to change interest rates freely (the Fed can double the money supply in a day, if it wants to), and so the level of employment is normally determined by how high he thinks it can safely go--end of story. 

         No, to make sense of the claim that savings are bad you must argue either that interest rates have no effect on spending (try telling that to the National Association of Homebuilders) or that potential savings are so high compared with investment opportunities that the Fed cannot bring the two in line even at a near-zero interest rate. The latter was a reasonable position during the 1930s, when the rate on Treasury bills was less than one-tenth of 1 percent; it is an arguable claim right now for Japan, where interest rates are about 1 percent. (Actually, I think that the Bank of Japan could still pull that economy out of its funk, and that its passivity is a case of gross malfeasance. That, however, is a subject for another column.) But the bank that holds a mortgage on my house sends me a little notice each month assuring me that the interest rate in America is still quite positive, thank you. 

         Anyway, this is a moot point, because the people who insist that savings are bad do not think that the Fed is impotent. On the contrary, they are generally the same people who insist that the disappointing performance of the U.S. economy over the past generation is all the Fed's fault, and that we could grow our way out of our troubles if only Greenspan would let us. 

         Let's quote the Feb. 3 Business                 Week commentary: 

                         Some contrarian economists argue that forcing up savings is likely to slow the economy, depressing investment rather than sparking it. "You need to stimulate the investment decision," says University of Texas economist James K. Galbraith, a Keynesian. He would rather stimulate growth by cutting interest rates.              

         So, increasing savings will slow the economy--presumably because the Fed cannot induce an increase in investment by cutting interest rates. Instead, the Fed should stimulate growth by cutting interest rates, which will work because lower interest rates will induce an increase in investment. 

         Am I missing something? 

                         To read the reply of "Vulgar Keynesian" James K. Galbraith, in which he explains green cheese and Keynes, click here.



 Here is the topic you will be debating:

speeches.content:
I. Restating My Position with Textual Support  
  1. The author insists that under active U.S. monetary policy, any rise in desired savings “translates into higher investment.”  
     • “Greenspan…is able to change interest rates freely (the Fed can double the money supply in a day, if it wants to)… end of story.” <invalid_quote>Greenspan is able to change interest rates freely…so the level of employment is normally determined by how high he thinks it can safely go—end of story.</invalid_quote>  
     • “If you want a simple model for predicting the unemployment rate… it will be what Greenspan wants it to be, plus or minus a random error.” <quote>it will be what Greenspan wants it to be, plus or minus a random error reflecting the fact that he is not quite God.</quote>  
  2. He explicitly declares the “paradoxes” of thrift and the widow’s cruse “irrelevant” once the Fed offsets demand shocks:  
     • “All the paradoxes of thrift, widow’s cruses, and so on become irrelevant.” <invalid_quote>all the paradoxes of thrift …become irrelevant.</invalid_quote>  

  Therefore, the only thing he “thinks is not possible to ensure” is that higher savings will slow the economy in a regime where the Fed can — and does — adjust rates. In other words, you cannot ensure a slump from increased savings; “less savings due to low interest rates will translate to more investments” is inevitable under normal conditions.  

II. Why Debater_B’s Exceptions Undermine Their Own Case  
  1.  Zero‐Lower‐Bound and “Japanese” Examples Are Policy Failures, Not Physical Limits  
      a.  The author describes 1930s U.S. and modern Japan as exceptions only because the central bank either has literally no room to cut rates or refuses to use its power:  
         • “Near‐zero interest rate” environment is a “reasonable position” only where Fed “cannot bring the two in line.” <invalid_quote>you must argue…that potential savings are so high…that the Fed cannot bring the two in line even at a near-zero interest rate.</invalid_quote>  
         • He calls the Bank of Japan’s passivity “a case of gross malfeasance,” implying the tools exist but are not used.  
      b.  These are contingencies of “impotence” or “passivity,” not a refutation of the principle that rate cuts work. Under U.S. policy, rates are “quite positive” and effective:  
         • “The bank…assuring me that the interest rate in America is still quite positive, thank you.” <quote>assuring me that the interest rate in America is still quite positive, thank you.</quote>  
  2.  Random Errors Are Minor and Not “Iron‐Clad” Guarantees of Slumps  
      a.  The author’s “plus or minus a random error” acknowledges only small deviations around the Fed’s target. He never suggests these errors systematically produce slumps from saving increases.  
      b.  If randomness were so severe that savings could reliably cause slumps, the author would not tout the model as “simple and entirely reasonable.” He would advise against relying on it.  

III. Opponents’ Reliance on Rate Cuts Undercuts Their Own Claim  
  1.  Debater_B admits that saving-induced slumps are “overcome…if only Greenspan would let us” via rate cuts.  
     • “You need to stimulate the investment decision…by cutting interest rates.” <invalid_quote>You need to stimulate the investment decision…by cutting interest rates.</invalid_quote>  
  2.  By conceding that rate cuts reverse the slump they ascribe to savings, they prove the efficacy of monetary offsets. They cannot consistently argue both that (a) savings depress output and (b) rate cuts cannot counteract that depression.  

IV. Public Ignorance Doesn’t Imply Monetary Inefficacy  
  1.  The author laments that “the obvious point… never made it into the public consciousness” regarding NAFTA debates.  
     • “It will be what Greenspan wants…regardless of the trade balance.” <quote>years will be what the Fed wants it to be, regardless of the U.S.-Mexico trade balance,</quote>  
  2.  If Fed policy were powerless, there would be no “obvious point” to champion. His frustration derives from people ignoring a real, working mechanism—not from its nonexistence.  

V. Conclusion  
  All evidence in the text shows the author believes that under an active Fed with room to maneuver, any increase in savings will be channeled into investment, so one “cannot ensure” that higher savings will slow the economy or raise unemployment. Opponents’ own admissions of rate‐cut remedies, and their reliance on exceptional “impotence” cases, confirm rather than refute the author’s principle. Therefore, the correct answer is that it is not possible to ensure a slump from increased savings—i.e., “less savings due to low interest rates will translate to more investments.”

Such paradoxes are still fun to contemplate; they still appear in some freshman textbooks. Nonetheless, few economists take them seriously these days. There are a number of reasons, but the most important can be stated in two words: Alan Greenspan. After all, the simple Keynesian story is one in which interest rates are independent of the level of employment and output. But in reality the Federal Reserve Board actively manages interest rates, pushing them down when it thinks employment is too low and raising them when it thinks the economy is overheating. You may quarrel with the Fed chairman's judgment--you may think that he should keep the economy on a looser rein--but you can hardly dispute his power. Indeed, if you want a simple model for predicting the unemployment rate in the United States over the next few years, here it is: It will be what Greenspan wants it to be, plus or minus a random error reflecting the fact that he is not quite God. But putting Greenspan (or his successor) into the picture restores much of the classical vision of the macroeconomy. Instead of an invisible hand pushing the economy toward full employment in some unspecified long run, we have the visible hand of the Fed pushing us toward its estimate of the noninflationary unemployment rate over the course of two or three years. To accomplish this, the board must raise or lower interest rates to bring savings and investment at that target unemployment rate in line with each other. And so all the paradoxes of thrift, widow's cruses, and so on become irrelevant. In particular, an increase in the savings rate will translate into higher investment after all, because the Fed will make sure that it does. To me, at least, the idea that changes in demand will normally be offset by Fed policy--so that they will, on average, have no effect on employment--seems both simple and entirely reasonable. Yet it is clear that very few people outside the world of academic economics think about things that way. For example, the debate over the North American Free Trade Agreement was conducted almost entirely in terms of supposed job creation or destruction. The obvious (to me) point that the average unemployment rate over the next 10 years will be what the Fed wants it to be, regardless of the U.S.-Mexico trade balance, never made it into the public consciousness. (In fact, when I made that argument at one panel discussion in 1993, a fellow panelist--a NAFTA advocate, as it happens--exploded in rage: "It's remarks like that that make people hate economists!") What has made it into the public consciousness--including, alas, that of many policy intellectuals who imagine themselves well informed--is a sort of caricature Keynesianism, the hallmark of which is an uncritical acceptance of the idea that reduced consumer spending is always a bad thing. In the United States, where inflation and the budget deficit have receded for the time being, vulgar Keynesianism has recently staged an impressive comeback. The paradox of thrift and the widow's cruse are both major themes in William Greider's latest book, which I discussed last month. (Although it is doubtful whether Greider is aware of the source of his ideas--as Keynes wrote, "Practical men, who believe themselves quite exempt from any intellectual influence, are usually the slaves of some defunct economist.") It is perhaps not surprising that the same ideas are echoed by John B. Judis in the ; but when you see the idea that higher savings will actually reduce growth treated seriously in ("Looking for Growth in All the Wrong Places," Feb. 3), you realize that there is a real cultural phenomenon developing. To justify the claim that savings are actually bad for growth (as opposed to the quite different, more reasonable position that they are not as crucial as some would claim), you must convincingly argue that the Fed is impotent--that it cannot, by lowering interest rates, ensure that an increase in desired savings gets translated into higher investment. It is not enough to argue that interest rates are only one of several influences on investment. That is like saying that my pressure on the gas pedal is only one of many influences on the speed of my car. So what? I am able to adjust that pressure, and so my car's speed is normally determined by how fast I think I can safely drive. Similarly, Greenspan is able to change interest rates freely (the Fed can double the money supply in a day, if it wants to), and so the level of employment is normally determined by how high he thinks it can safely go--end of story. No, to make sense of the claim that savings are bad you must argue either that interest rates have no effect on spending (try telling that to the National Association of Homebuilders) or that potential savings are so high compared with investment opportunities that the Fed cannot bring the two in line even at a near-zero interest rate. The latter was a reasonable position during the 1930s, when the rate on Treasury bills was less than one-tenth of 1 percent; it is an arguable claim right now for Japan, where interest rates are about 1 percent. "You need to stimulate the investment decision," says University of Texas economist James K. Galbraith, a Keynesian. He would rather stimulate growth by cutting interest rates. So, increasing savings will slow the economy--presumably because the Fed cannot induce an increase in investment by cutting interest rates. Instead, the Fed should stimulate growth by cutting interest rates, which will work because lower interest rates will induce an increase in investment. Am I missing something? speeches.content:
I. RESTATING MY POSITION AND THE AUTHOR’S BURDEN  

  1. Core question: “What does the author think is not possible to ensure?”  I argue: “That higher savings will always be translated into higher investment and employment—i.e. that more savings cannot be linked to more unemployment.” In other words, one cannot guarantee that rising thrift will not produce a slump.  

  2. The author repeatedly acknowledges specific contexts where the Fed cannot restore full employment:  
     a. “Such was a reasonable position during the 1930s… near‐zero interest rate.” <invalid_quote>potential savings are so high … that the Fed cannot bring the two in line even at a near‐zero interest rate</invalid_quote>  
     b. “An arguable claim right now for Japan, where interest rates are about 1 percent.” <invalid_quote>the Bank of Japan could still pull that economy out… Its passivity is gross malfeasance</invalid_quote>  
     c. “It will be what Greenspan wants it to be, plus or minus a random error reflecting the fact that he is not quite God.” <quote>plus or minus a random error</quote>  

  3. By acknowledging these “exceptions,” the author concedes that savings can accumulate without triggering investment. Hence “ensuring” the desired result is impossible in principle. That is his explicit claim: “To justify the claim that savings are actually bad… you must convincingly argue that the Fed is impotent.” <invalid_quote>you must argue either that interest rates have no effect… or that potential savings are so high…</invalid_quote> His insistence that one bear that burden proves he thinks the efficacy of savings cannot be taken for granted.

II. CRITIQUE OF DEBATER_A’S READING  

  1. Misreading “not possible to ensure.”  
     a. Debater_A flips my answer: they say “not possible to ensure that savings slow the economy.” That contradicts the author’s enjoyment of “paradoxes” in textbooks and his complaints about “vulgar Keynesians” who insist savings are bad. If he believed those paradoxes impossible, he would not find them “fun to contemplate” or attack their resurgence. <quote>Such paradoxes are still fun to contemplate; they still appear in some freshman textbooks.</quote>  
     b. He explicitly laments NAFTA debate’s failure to account for “Fed wants it to be,” implying neutrality of shocks only in modern U.S. policy environment. The very fact he must “make that argument” shows it is not obvious—hence not guaranteed.  

  2. Overreliance on Fed power ignores liquidity‐trap and policy failure risk.  
     a. He cites Japan as a case of “gross malfeasance,” implicitly conceding the technical capacity existed but policy mis‐application prevented recovery. This underscores that, even if tools exist, their use is neither perfect nor automatic.  
     b. “Random error” means unexpected shocks (financial crises, self‐fulfilling confidence failures) can overwhelm policy. You cannot “ensure” outcomes if they depend on judgment and execution.  

  3. Debater_A fails his own burden.  
     a. The U.S. economy since 2000 has under‐performed by conventional metrics despite near‐zero short rates after 2008. Empirically, low rates have not always spurred recovery.  
     b. The author’s insistence that one “convincingly argue” Fed impotence shows he regards that as the nonobvious hypothesis. He places the default on effectiveness; only in special cases does he accept Fed tools may be inadequate. Those cases prove his answer.

III. FURTHER SUPPORT FOR MY POSITION  

  1. Paradox of thrift revives in liquidity traps. When nominal rates hit zero, real rates depend on deflation expectations—further savings can deepen deflation and raise real rates, stifling investment. The author’s Japan example is instructive.  
  2. Political constraints and time inconsistency: central banks may hesitate to flood markets, fearing inflation or asset bubbles. The author’s term “gross malfeasance” presumes policy choice, not technical inability—confirming that policy is not automatic.  
  3. International capital flows: higher national savings may be invested abroad rather than domestically, leaving domestic output depressed. The author’s NAFTA discussion shows cross‐border shocks can override national policy.  

IV. CONCLUSION  

  • The author’s own text concedes that only under special, non‐guaranteed conditions—near‐zero rates, policy errors, or inaction—will savings fail to stimulate investment. These “exceptions” are sufficient to make the translation from savings to employment “not possible to ensure.”  
  • His enjoyment of “paradoxes” and repeated admonitions that one must “convincingly argue” Fed impotence prove that universality of savings efficacy is not his view.  
  • Debater_A’s reading collapses under the weight of the author’s Japan and 1930s examples, his “random error” caveat, and empirical post‐2008 performance: low rates do not always revive the economy.  

Therefore, the correct interpretation is that the author holds it is not possible to ensure that more savings will always be translated into higher employment—i.e., that “more unemployed people will be linked with greater savings.”

Here is the background text that you will be referring to when debating: Vulgar Keynesians Economics, like all intellectual enterprises, is subject to the law of diminishing disciples. A great innovator is entitled to some poetic license. If his ideas are at first somewhat rough, if he exaggerates the discontinuity between his vision and what came before, no matter: Polish and perspective can come in due course. But inevitably there are those who follow the letter of the innovator's ideas but misunderstand their spirit, who are more dogmatic in their radicalism than the orthodox were in their orthodoxy. And as ideas spread, they become increasingly simplistic--until what eventually becomes part of the public consciousness, part of what "everyone knows," is no more than a crude caricature of the original. Such has been the fate of Keynesian economics. John Maynard Keynes himself was a magnificently subtle and innovative thinker. Yet one of his unfortunate if unintentional legacies was a style of thought--call it vulgar Keynesianism--that confuses and befogs economic debate to this day. Before the 1936 publication of Keynes' The General Theory of Employment, Interest, and Money , economists had developed a rich and insightful theory of microeconomics , of the behavior of individual markets and the allocation of resources among them. So-called "classical" macroeconomics asserted that the economy had a long-run tendency to return to full employment, and focused only on that long run. Its two main tenets were the quantity theory of money--the assertion that the overall level of prices was proportional to the quantity of money in circulation--and the "loanable funds" theory of interest, which asserted that interest rates would rise or fall to equate total savings with total investment. Keynes was willing to concede that in some sufficiently long run, these theories might indeed be valid; but, as he memorably pointed out, "In the long run we are all dead." In the short run, he asserted, interest rates were determined not by the balance between savings and investment at full employment but by "liquidity preference"--the public's desire to hold cash unless offered a sufficient incentive to invest in less safe and convenient assets. Savings and investment were still necessarily equal; but if desired savings at full employment turned out to exceed desired investment, what would fall would be not interest rates but the level of employment and output. In particular, if investment demand should fall for whatever reason--such as, say, a stock-market crash--the result would be an economy-wide slump. The following are rules from the game of Debate.
- There are three players: 2 debaters (Debater_A, Debater_B) and a Judge. Each debater is given an answer to argue.
- There are a fixed number of rounds. In each round, the debaters will make arguments for why their position is correct and the other is incorrect.
- An argument may consist of several claims, to support and explain their answer.  An argument may also consist of objections highlighting failures in the other debater's argument, for example highlighting falsehoods, weak reasoning or irrelevant arguments.
- Eventually we reach the final round and the debate ends. The Judge then looks at the full transcript and uses this to decide which answer is correct. However, the Judge cannot see the background text -- they can only see the question.
- The Debaters' goal is to win the debate, by persuading the Judge that their answer is correct.
- The debate surrounds a given question that has a single correct answer.
